question: Question_02_(c)
statement:
\textbf{Short-Answer Question. Simplify your answer as much as possible
and show your work.}

Suppose that $\displaystyle f(1) = -1$, $\displaystyle g(-1) = 2$,
$\displaystyle f'(1) = -2$, and $\displaystyle g'(-1) = 3$. Find
$\displaystyle h'(-1)$, where

\[\displaystyle 
h(x) = f(x^2)g(x)\]
hints:
Try finding $\displaystyle h'(x)$ from the definition of
$\displaystyle h(x)$.
Apply the product rule to find $\displaystyle h'(x)$.
